comments.commentBody:
Why is there no mention in the article that the E. coli in question almost certainly originated with meat, not vegetables?

The suggestion that all vegetables be irradiated to prevent infection is chilling to me; a similar procedure is being done to California almonds, where all almonds grown in the state of California are required to be irradiated, pasteurized, or chemically processed, even if they're sold as "raw." This processing will automatically render them nutritionally inferior.

It is insanity to require that food be dead before we can consume it; a more sensible way would be to require that basic safety standards be in place. Why can't humans even handle that?

Why is there no mention in the article that the E. coli in question almost certainly originated with meat, not vegetables?

The suggestion that all vegetables be irradiated to prevent infection is chilling to me; a similar procedure is being done to California almonds, where all almonds grown in the state of California are required to be irradiated, pasteurized, or chemically processed, even if they're sold as "raw." This processing will automatically render them nutritionally inferior.

It is insanity to require that food be dead before we can consume it; a more sensible way would be to require that basic safety standards be in place. Why can't humans even handle that?

The only plausible Republican candidate who can talk about the economy is Romney, late of Bain & Co., a guy who leveraged millions out of jobs. And because of Massachusetts health care and Mormonism, he is no real threat. Pawlenty appears like a high plains corporate shill next to Obama. (his name sounds like some off-brand farina.) Most of the public and corporate kingpins would recoil at the prospect of the Republican women.

The GOP has no solutions except to make the little guy pay for the sins of the fat cats. And they have no viable candidates except talking heads with shibboleths.

The lack of new jobs is disappointing. But the resurgence of the auto makers is a good thing. In addition, people realize that Obama inherited a lot from Bush, including foreign matters, one of which was resolved nicely about a month ago.

Even if the economy gets worse, Obama should still win. If Obama loses, a lot of people will be surprised, including UK odds makers.

I am a life long Liberal Democrat and of course I would like to see more job growth. He has made a lot of mistakes that I am disappointed about but I can't see voting Republican when they are so far from the issues I believe in. Does anyone think anybody R or D can solve this problem? No one in office seems to be able to think clearly.

How about promoting "healthy lifestyle choices" instead of "diets" that only promote weight loss when we restrict and deprive ourselves of essential nutrients? I mean there are such things as healthy carbohydrates - fruits, vegetables, et cetera - that provide vitamins and minerals essential to a healthy lifestyle.

Assuming this is study is correct - can we please learn some more about the different sorts of carbs (sugar, fructose corn syrup, refined carbs, whole grains, etc) and their effects on the human body? Also, if I switch to fatty sausage and hamburger, I will eat a lot of extra hormones and antibiotics - unless I buy the expensive meat on the farmers market.
Whilst this study can be debated, there are plenty of other studies that suggest that eating red meat increases cancer risk.
Now what?

All the yo-yo dieting and high fat diets, may work out for the heart, but what about the pancreas, and the rise in pancreatic cancer deaths.  My brother died young of this disease and I feel his many years of Atkins dieting was not a healthy way of eating for him.  Genetics are a factor we all must consider as well.  Testing for genetic risk factors should not be cost prohibitive as prevention is worth a pound of cure and the continued presence of loved ones in our lives.

Even though Obama has many flaws, I am happy that has been president during the post Bush/ post financial meltdown era. I shudder to think of the stewardship of the country under McCain and Palin.

http://energypricedata.blogspot.com/
the key to the job will be with the programs which affect seniors. right now the pres and dems are + 1. if they touch these programs in any way it will be a new ball game.

"No president since Franklin Roosevelt has won re-election with unemployment above 7.2 percent" and the Republicans no this which is why they're doing everything in their power to sabotage the economy. They threaten to end Medicare, shut the government down, default on the national debt and whatever else they can think of to create uncertainty and slow the economy. If the unemployment rate gets below 8% they'll start a trade war with China over the value of their currency if they have to.

We do not have a federal deficit crisis. That is nonsense. What we have is an unemployment crisis and a crisis of falling demand and revenue. Romer is right. The president is not trying hard enough to create more jobs and restart the economy. His emphasis on deficit-cutting is a disaster, since it allows the Republicans to set the terms of the whole debate about the recession and jobs.

In terms of economics, budget-cutting during a recession almost guarantees that unemployment will go up and that demand will become weaker. If the Dems give in to the Repubs and agree to big budget cuts, we might even have a double-dip recession, pushing the recovery off even further into the future. Cutting the budget during a recession is economic madness. It ruined the economy in 1937 when FDR tried it; it ruined the Japanese economy in 1997 when they tried it; and it is now hurting the British economy because the conservatives slashed the budget. Cutting the budget during a recession is the perfect recipe for hurting the economy, increasing unemployment, causing lower revenues, and therefore *increasing* the deficit. And since the financial reform bill was mostly window dressing, there will doubtless be another big recession coming up in five years or so. We will enter the era of permanent recession for the foreseeable future.

If Obama joins the Repubs in calling for big budget cuts instead of a new economic stimulus bill and robust job-creation measures, he doesn't deserve to be the Dem candidate in 2012. He should make up his mind. If he wants to cut the budget and increase unemployment and thus raise the deficit, he should step down and run as an independent or a Republican in 2012. It's time for Obama to listen to Romer and to the majority of Americans and start fighting hard for more jobs and for economic recovery.

17 months to the election? At that point in Reagan's presidency, according to the bureau of labor statistics, unemployment was 10.2% for May 1983. In fact, under RR, unemployment was over 10% for 10 months straight from September 1982 to June 1983 compared to Obama's one month, and over 9% for 19 months. It was 7.5% when he won the election and took office which is lower than what Obama inherited.

As for critics of Obama's stimulus policies as being socialist spending (#6 Dale), I'd like to "remind" them that about $250 billion was in tax cuts. I'd also like to "remind" them that Reagan also enacted a very Keynesian policy on 2 counts: lower taxes during the recession/recovery and a dramatic increase in spending, according to the Bureau of Economic Analysis of the Commerce dept. In Keynesian fashion, he also raised taxes, albeit quietly, after the recovery was well under way, not that he understood any of this, of course.

The main differences: a) the dems played nice in the early 1980s compared to the absolute non-cooperation of current republicans, and b) what Obama inherited - housing and financial crises, 2 unfunded wars and other increased spending despite cuts in taxes, and the resulting already exploding deficits - was much worse than what Reagan inherited. It is the non-cooperative republicans and blue-dogs who are the ones responsible for this continuing misery, and both dems and republicans and voters for creating the situation over the years, but, critics on the right will never see that, either out of vested interest (choice) or willful ignorance and laziness about checking facts.

When access to cr4edit expands teh economy will heal. However, the government is picking at the scabs instead and re-opening wounds. It has been almost 4 years since the Lehman collapse and 3 years under Obama but we still have uncertainty in lending and entirely new and unpredictable rules forthcoming wioth anew agency to start in July. After 4 years PLEASE just write a new set of rules and let everyone move on.

I'm fairly livid at Obama and the dems for not doing enough about the economy. The only thing that saves him in my book is that the GOP are SOOOO much worse. Their prescription for this recession has been to slash and burn regular workers and give more tax cuts to large corporations that aren't hiring despite having plenty of cash to do so. Scott Walker and Paul Ryan have shown us what's to come if a republican wins. No thank you.

BTW, I'm an independent and I know other independents have been completely put off by the republicans' worthless response to the recession. It's like we have dumb and dumber here between the two political parties. Potential primary challengers in both parties (for all incumbents), the field is wide open for you in my book. Come up with a good econ plan so we can vote for you and throw the worthless members of the status quo out.

Half the people who voted for him probably never worked more than a year in their life anyway. They will be too lazy next time to get out and vote as fascination has worn off. So probably a one termer.
No words for this. Just grunts of dissatisfaction. Goodbye Ben. Thanks for the clever and so Timesian blog.
Oh, no, not another departure from the pages of the NYT! Sorry your column won't be continuing. What's up with the Times?!
Oh no! Ben, this has been fun -- and PLEASE leave the past posts on NYTimes.com -- they're so much fun to browse through!! -- Pat

"Is there any political appetite for something that would resemble another large Keynesian stimulus? Obviously no. You can say that's what we should do and you'd probably be right, but that's pretty academic."

But political leadership involves translating what is academic into real policy through the force of debate, argument, and persuasion. Most of us don't have degrees in economics. We're not going to espouse a major shift in policy unless that policy is explained in concrete, understandable terms.

That's what leadership is about. It's not about reading polls and deciding that a Keynseian stimulus must be averted because it has no public support. Leadership involves using the bully pulpit to explain the need for a Keynesian stimulus over and over and over again using every rhetorical tool in one's arsenal.

Franklin Delano Roosevelt didn't just sit around measuring public opinion. He MOLDED public opinion through the strength of his argument, his personality, and his extraordinary rhetoric. That's what we need in today's leaders.

I like Obama a lot and I will vote for him in the next election. But I don't think he fully appreciates the extent to which he can use the bully pulpit to advance causes that are not immediately popular. If Obama would use the full force of his intelligence and linguistic skill to advance sound economic policies, he might discover that, like Roosevelt, he, too, can move mountains.

Always leave them wanting more.

Aloha 'Oe

Schott's Vocab is dead! Long live... Schott's Vocab!

This is a serious bummer. For real, yo.

And i thought that the republicans were elected on a promise of a laser like focus on creating jobs.  Instead we get Mitch McConnell saying that his agenda is to make President Obama a one term president.  Add that to the current bone headed theory of what's good for the 2 percenters is good for the job market, and you have the recipe for the disaster we live every day.  To blame President Obama for the disruptive policies of the conservatives is specious, and is certainly a republican talking point. Does Appelbaum work for the republican rumor machine?.
Black bug's blood.  (Learned from my father many years ago.)
Arrrggghhh!!!!!

The GOP has no incentive to help Obama with job creation, number one; anyone voting GOP because of unemployment doesn't know the history of the party, number two.

Fool me once, shame on you......fool me twice..
